Reagan Rath: Swimming and Lacrosse

Governor Cuomo has revised the timetable for returning school budget/Board of Education ballots. Here’s how to make sure your vote gets counted.

Any hand-delivered ballots must be in one of the lockboxes at the district office (15 Quade Street) by 5 p.m. tomorrow, Tuesday, June 9th.

Ballots that are mailed via the U.S. Postal Service will be accepted up until 5 p.m. on Tuesday, June 16th. Don’t delay—get your ballot into the mail now! (For reference, GFSD ballot packets were put in the mail on Monday, June 1 and arrived in residents’ mailboxes Thursday-Friday, June 4-5.)

All votes will be counted beginning at 5 p.m. on the 16th. The ballot counting process will be live-streamed, and that link will be on gfsd.org.

Read the budget newsletter, view the budget hearing, see a sample ballot, and review the full budget book details here: https://www.gfsd.org/about-us/school-budget/

Our #GFNation Tech Team keeps spreading the love for our local heroes, delivering more than three dozen 3D-printed face shields to the Renal Dialysis Center of Glens Falls!

The Center is still providing live-giving kidney dialysis to patients every day through the COVID-19 pandemic, and staff members were running low on the face shields they use to keep safe. Steve Spory and Jess Maynard heard about the need and delivered 40 face shields to the facility.

One of the nurses said to a family member, “we were all very touched that the school thought of us! Some tears when we put them on before the smiles! Very emotional!!”

The effort has involved re-deploying overhead transparency sheets from our empty classrooms, printing up to 24 headband pieces a day from six MakerBot 3D printers re-positioned in the High School's 21st Century Learning Space, and assembling each piece with rubber bands from the main office.

❤️🖤💪🏻

A drive-through food pantry is happening today at 10 AM for all #GFNation families at Aviation Mall! The Glens Falls Rotary and Glens Falls Kiwanis, along with the Warren County Sheriff's Office will be directing traffic through a series of tented stations.

The first station will be registration with the Salvation Army. Each subsequent station will provide various food items (e.g. meat, canned goods, produce, dry goods), toilet articles and masks (donated by SAIL) and hand sanitizer (donated by Springbrook Hollow Farm Distillery). A box will be placed in the back of each vehicle and the various items will be placed in the box at each station.

Drivers will not get out of their cars, and all volunteers will be masked and gloved and will observe the social distancing guidelines established by the CDC.

This distribution will be on a first come, first served basis. Many thanks to the Aviation Mall for providing the space for this much-needed event and to all of the volunteers who will make sure the event runs smoothly.

GFMS seventh-grader Jason Hall has been recognized for making a big difference in the lives of children in our region!

Having established a bottle and can drive to benefit Operation Santa Claus, Jason has donated several thousand dollars to the non-profit that provides new clothes to children in Warren, Washington, Essex, Northern Saratoga, and Hamilton Counties in December.

The plaque — given to Jason by the Operation Santa Claus committee — reads “Congratulations for establishing your “Cans for Kids” project which has raised many thousands of dollars to help clothe and feed less fortunate children at Christmas time.”

This holiday season alone, Jason’s efforts brought in $1,300. He runs the bottle and can collection year-round, and has been doing so for two years. Way to go, Jason!
❤️🖤

#GFNation's Superintendent's Conference Day on Friday featured a day-long intensive on one of our district initiatives for the school year: exploring Social Emotional Learning and what it means to be a trauma-informed school that uses trauma-transforming practices. Our entire staff talked about the neuroscience behind traumatic childhood experiences, and worked through strategies to respond to affected students with leader Dave Melnick of NFI, VT. We are learning how to "combat relational poverty with good relationships," re-categorize stress behaviors, and intervene with “I notice… I wonder… What if…” We are also imagining what restorative justice practices could look like in our schools.

Join our efforts! Interested in learning more about childhood trauma and how the entire school community can help affected children learn? Read one of our staff's pre-conference day reading requirements here: https://www.adoptioncouncil.org/publications/2013/09/adoption-advocate-no-63
